description: From Latin coeliacus, from Ancient Greek κοιλιακός (koiliakós), from κοιλία (koilía, “belly”); surface analysis, coel- +‎ -i- +‎ -ac. Cognate with coelom.

entries.meaning: (UK, anatomy) Relating to the abdomen, or to the cavity of the abdomen.
examples: The coeliac plexus is formed by the two interconnecting coeliac ganglia which lie either side of the coeliac artery.

entries.meaning: (UK) Abbreviation of coeliac disease; used attributively.
examples: Most coeliac patients are childen, the symptoms showing when cereals are first introduced in their diet.
